column1: North Platte is a city in and the county seat of Lincoln County
column3: United States. It is located in the west-central part of the state
column5: at the confluence of the North and South Platte Rivers forming the Platte River. The population was 24
column6: 733 at the 2010 census.North Platte is a railroad town; Union Pacific Railroad's large Bailey Yard is located within the city. Today
column7: North Platte is served only by freight trains
column8: but during World War II the city was famous for the North Platte Canteen. Tens of thousands of volunteers from North Platte and surrounding towns met the troop trains passing through North Platte

column1: North Platte is the principal city of the North Platte Micropolitan Statistical Area

column1: North Platte was established in 1866 when the Union Pacific Railroad was extended to that point. It was named from the North Platte River.On July 13
column3: black North Platte resident Louis "Slim" Seeman was accused of shooting and killing Edward Green
column4: a North Platte police officer. Following the incident
column5: a mob of white residents of North Platte killed Seeman
column7: telling black residents to leave North Platte. Fearing mob violence
column8: most of North Platte's black residents fled.

column4: of which 13.20 square miles (34.19 km2) is land and 0.19 square miles (0.49 km2) is water.

column1: North Platte experiences a dry continental climate similar to that of the Nebraska High Plains
column3: and
column4: with an annual average precipitation of 20.22 inches (514 mm)
column5: barely avoids semi-arid classification; it is part of USDA Hardiness zone 5a. The normal monthly mean temperature ranges from 25.0 °F (−3.9 °C) in January to 74.3 °F (23.5 °C) in July. On average
column6: there are 3.5 afternoons that reach 100 °F (37.8 °C) or higher
column8: 33 afternoons that do not climb above freezing
column9: and 13 mornings with a low of 0 °F (−17.8 °C) or below. The average window for freezing temperatures is September 26 thru May 10
column10: allowing a growing season of 138 days. Extreme temperatures officially range from −35 °F (−37.2 °C) on January 15
column14: 1954; the record cold daily maximum is −15 °F (−26.1 °C) on January 14
column18: the record warm daily minimum is 80 °F (26.7 °C) on July 25
column19: 1940.Precipitation is greatest in May and June and has ranged from 10.01 inches (254.3 mm) in 1931 to 33.44 inches (849.4 mm) in 1951. Snowfall averages 28.5 inches (0.72 m) per season
column20: and has historically ranged from 3.0 inches (0.08 m) in 1903–04 to 66.3 inches (1.68 m) in 1979–80; the average window for measurable (≥0.1 inches or 0.0025 metres) snowfall is October 30 thru April 11

column1: North Platte is home to North Platte Regional Airport. United Express serves the airport with twice-daily service to Denver International Airport.
North Platte is home to the world's largest rail yard
column2: Bailey Yard. The Golden Spike Tower and Visitor Center is an eight-story building which overlooks the expansive classification yard and engine facilities. The tower and visitor center are open to the public year-round.North Platte was the western terminus of the Union Pacific Railway from the summer of 1867 until the next section to Laramie
column3: Wyoming
column4: was opened the following summer. Even though Congress had authorized the building of the Transcontinental Railroad in 1862
column5: it was only extended as far as Nebraska City by the start of the summer of 1867. The 275-mile section from Nebraska City to North Platte was completed in less than six weeks.Lincoln County Historical Museum contains a display detailing the history of the North Platte Canteen
column6: which greeted 6.5 million service personnel from Christmas Day 1941 through April 1
column7: 1946. It also contains a Prairie Village with local landmark homes and other buildings
column8: including a Pony Express station and pioneer church among many others.Buffalo Bill Ranch State Historical Park is located near North Platte
column9: a Nebraska living history park about Buffalo Bill Cody. The park includes his actual house known as Scout's Rest Ranch. The park is two miles west of U.S. Highway 83 along U.S. Highway 30.Every June
column10: North Platte hosts the annual "Nebraskaland Days". The event includes parades
column14: and food events. It draws over 100
column15: 000 attendees every year.North Platte is host to the annual Miss Nebraska pageant
column16: an official preliminary for the Miss America Organization.
